“Freedom” is a tricky concept as there are several meanings: pure oxygen is free of contaminants from other chemicals, inmates in the US prison are free from the need to cook for themselves but they are not free to travel as they wish. Arguments that something supports freedom of one type may demonstrate that the something restricts or eliminates freedom of another type. Without some clarity, one can easily be intellectually bamboozled. The Liberal philosophy that underpinned the founding of the US generally referred to the rights and liberties of individuals when using the word “freedom”. To protect rights and liberties people formed governments with specific responsibilities: to protect the Commonwealth from external threats, to protect individuals from the coercion of other individuals (coercion against their persons or their property), and to enforce the agreements (contracts) necessary for peaceful human interaction and exchange of their labor and property. Fulfillment of the first of these responsibilities requires a military of some sort. But the military is a tool of government and can be used by the government to protect rights and liberties (freedoms in that sense) or to violate those rights and liberties and prevent their exercise by the people. The government can also use a military for other, unrelated purposes. Perhaps you are questioning whether the government is using the military for legitimate purposes (protection of the society from external threats) or for other, illegitimate purposes. That is a very good question. The attacks on the World Trade Center – in September 2001, and earlier – are the kinds of things we legitimately expect government to protect us from. But it was too late once the attackers got on board the aircraft, and subsequent investigations revealed that the attacks were organized and planned by forces outside of the country. It was apparent that, for the government to do its job properly, the government must operate outside of the US, attacking organizations that were planning to harm us. As we have organized our government, this meant we needed to use the military.  Whether or not we needed to remain at war, fighting foreign entities and killing people, for 13 years is a very good question. But the question really is not whether the military is protecting our freedoms but whether the government is appropriately using the military or whether the government is inappropriately using a military for other purposes. Inappropriate use of government power is always a danger and we should always be on guard against it. So, in my opinion, a more appropriate question is “Is the government using the military to protect our rights and liberties or is it using the military inappropriately?” I think it is mixed. We have an enemy that is actively working to harm our society and us as individuals and has been doing so for several decades. Our government has been actively using our military to fight this threat for only 13 years; perhaps we should continue to use the military to fight the continuing threat or perhaps we should withdraw the military and use other means that the government has at its disposal. The military is a very blunt tool and its continued use may no longer be appropriate. It seems that the government has been using the military for other purposes and that the military has, on occasion, been acting to pursue its own interests and the interests of senior officers and the several military branches. I think the country needs the debate your question has triggered.

Like most things in life, the answer is probably "It's complicated." Protecting the freedom and safety of US Citizens is undoubtedly the goal of most service members.  Every soldier, airman, marine, or sailor I have known has articulated this as the core of their service (along with more practical concerns like paying the bills, career training, etcetera). Some military operations and interventions do undoubtedly make US citizens safer.  Dead terrorists are preferable to living ones, in my humble opinion. For example - unless you buy into one of the variety of 9/11 "Truther" conspiracies (I do not), the Afghan conflict can easily be seen as an effort to seek retribution for those responsible for one of the bloodiest acts of terrorism in our nation's history.  In our attempt to eradicate the Taliban and Al Qaeda, we also sent a message - basically, don't fuck with us, you won't like what happens next.  (Whether the message actually deterred anyone is up for debate, I suppose.) Without any military, our freedom would certainly be in jeopardy as well as our safety. But the military, like any large organization, is a complicated entity.  It is wielded by politicians, who often have motives that are (at best) also complicated. Our foreign policy has at times been disastrous in its long term effects.  Our wars have not always been waged with clear goals, or clear moral rationale.  I said earlier that I prefer dead terrorists to live ones; I also prefer that people not become terrorists, and in some cases our government has actively created the terrorists our soldiers have later faced. A lot of people point to this as evidence of vast corruption on the part of our politicians, or of the insidious influence of the military industrial complex.  In my mind, such summations - while they may contain more than a few grains of truth - are overly simplistic (even when they're hopelessly convoluted).  The world is too complex to reduce our nation's history of wars to some sort of economic conspiracy on the part of Lockheed Martin; that sort of reasoning is intellectually lazy. The reality is, we live in a fractured, broken, complicated, unpredictable world, filled with imperfect humans who make at least as many bad choices as good ones.  So, yes, some of our conflicts have been ill-advised, and some of our military actions have been questionable.  We have committed atrocities, and we have created future enemies. I hate to sound trite, but what do you expect?  Perfection?  That's an ideal to strive toward, but its unachievable.  That doesn't mean we don't strive to do better, but it does mean that the mistakes, fuckups, and tragedies don't somehow overrule or blot out the good that's been done. You may disagree with the war on terror, and you may have good reasons for doing so.  You can point to atrocities and abuses committed by our country, and you'd be right.  But it's hard to argue that we're the bad guys in a war against people who behead journalists on video, throw acid on young women's faces, or gun down children looking for an education. Our national motives may not always be completely pure, and our methods may not always live up to our best ideals.  But if it comes down to it, there's us, and we're imperfect - and then there's evil.  The conflict is always going to be messy. On the balance of things, our servicemen do far more good than bad in the world.  They carry on traditions of duty, honor, brotherhood, and dedication to country that are sadly lacking in many quarters of our society.  And any one of them would give their life to protect our country, even if it is an imperfect place. So, in my opinion, yes, they do protect my freedom, and yours.

Individual members of the military fight because they are ordered to do so, and sworn to obey their orders. The reason for the fight lies with the agendas and motives of the ones giving the orders. Sometimes it can be difficult to discern exactly what justifies the military operations. In recent history, we've seen the First Gulf War, whose purpose seemed clear enough: liberate Kuwait and remove the threat to Saudi Arabia. The mission was clear, and achievement could be effectively measured. Indeed, all this happened. The Second Gulf War was not so clear cut. Saddam's opponents believed (so they said) he illegally possessed WMD's (weapons of mass destruction). He was challenged to disclose them to inspectors and get rid of them, otherwise we would attack and do the job ourselves. He did not comply, so we went to war. And while the initial combat operations are long over, the war has transformed into the ugly conflict we pursue at this moment. And no WMD's were ever discovered. The problem with this war was that there was no clearly defined final disposition; it was assumed that the native population would endorse a democratic government. They did not. The "war on terror" is a bit more accessible in terms of understanding the threat, especially when it takes shape within our own borders. But it is much more difficult to "fight." So, how does any of this relate to "fighting for freedom?" The answer is historical. After WWII, military and policy thinkers realized that the continental US was not protected by the oceans separating it from the rest of the world. Thus a deliberate decision was made to abandon an isolationist approach, and arrange for any future engagements to be fought "over there." Not here. Together with an expanding global military presence, a global economy (with foreign oil as a key component) created situations in which the US economy -and therefore, its people- could be put at risk in many new ways. While our "freedom" might not be challenged by attacking hordes on our own shores, it certainly could be compromised by challenges to our economic and political strength, world-wide. And so, protection of our "interests" takes shape in many and varied operations, all of which may be collectively understood as "taking the fight to the enemy." The fighting itself, as visceral as ever, finds justification in much more abstract areas. Hope that helps.

Yes.  In 1904, Secretary of War Elihu Root reoriented the Army away from constabulary duties to a mission focused on defeating the conventional forces of other nation-states. This view has shaped United States military culture since at least World War II and continues to this day. Whether the rationale of a modern war against terrorism, again, changes the military's mission towards domestic order is yet to be seen. Many of the men who met in Philadelphia to draft the U.S. Constitution had the experience of serving with the Continental Army.  Our nation's Founders like George Washington, James Madison, and Alexander Hamilton were  aware of the dangers external enemies posed to the new republic. The British and Spanish were not only on the frontiers of the new nation. In many cases they were within the frontiers, allying with the Indians and attempting to entice frontier settlements to split off from the country. The Constitutional Convention voted on, and accepted, the need for a standing army but sought to maintain control by the appropriations power of Congress, which the Founders viewed as the branch of government closest to "the people".
